logging

Class LOGGER

  • java.lang.Object
    • logging.LOGGER

  • public class LOGGER
extends java.lang.Object
    Version:
    1.0.170322
    Author:
    Nik4053

    Created with the help of this tutorial: http://www.vogella.com/tutorials/Logging/article.html

    And is therefore released under Eclipse Public License - v 1.0

    ____________________________________________________________________________

    This class is used for creating the Logger.

    Setup:

    First you have to import the logger:

    import logging.LOGGER;

    If you want the logs to be saved in different files for every thread you are logging set:

    LOGGER.enableDifferentLogs(true); if not then LOGGER.enableDifferentLogs(false);

    In order to get an output you have to add a Logger by using the Method:

    LOGGER.addLogger(Thread.currentThread().getId());

    If enableDifferentLogs(boolean)/(boolean createDifferentLogs) is set to true:

    Make sure to use the Method addLoger at the start of every new thread, or else this thread wont be logged.

    commands:

    LOGGER.setLevel(Level.INFO); sets the LogLevel to info. Only info, or more important Messages will be written to the log. You can change the Level. to every other log Level.

    Level sorted from highest to lowest priority:

    severe>warning>info>finest

    If you set the logLevel to LOGGER.setLevel(off);} no logs will be written anymore

    you can create a new log entry by using one of the following commands:

    Easy:

    LOGGER.logger."Level"(String); Set "Level" to the log level you want it to be like: LOGGER.logger.warning(String);

    to write an error log containing the an exception use: LOGGER.info(getStackTrace(e)); where e is the variable where the catched exception is stored

    Advanced:

    LOGGER.logger.log(Level, String, object); -> LOGGER.logger.log( Level.SEVERE, "This is a message", e ); or LOGGER.logger.log(Level.SEVERE, e.getMessage(), e); where e is the variable where the catched exception is stored

    For more info use: LOGGER.logger.log(Level.SEVERE,"Exception: "+ e.getMessage() + " at line " + Thread.currentThread().getStackTrace()[1].getLineNumber(), e);

    To log the name of the Method that is currently running you can use:

    LOGGER.logger.log(Level.INFO,"StartMethod: " + Thread.currentThread().getStackTrace()[1].getClassName() + " " + Thread.currentThread().getStackTrace()[1].getMethodName() + "()");
